 As someone who hates deficits and loves science, this one is a rock and a hard place for me. My understanding is that the big science projects provide benefits many times their cost in new discoveries that help mankind and advanced technology. If so, it seems like we would be promoting these kinds of projects. However I would like to see a committee of scientist setting priorities instead of politicians. 
 
 I’m not an expert in world hunger, but from what I understand, most of the world hunger is because of political unrest, not from lack of food.

Every dime we have spent on space has been worth it. Not so much because of what we did in space, but because of what we developed to do it.
 
 The microcomputer is worth all that we spend/t alone. Without it, imagine the world. It wouldn't have been developed without the space program.
 
 There are literally thousands of innovations that we use in everyday life born out of the space program.
 
 Rocks don't interest me, taking pretty pictures don't interest me, but the technology that we have and will develop as a result are worth 100 fold what we paid.

I agree that money that has been spent on space exploration has been well worth it. The space program has been responsible for a huge number of innovations.
 
 I think the politics of the decision were wrong, though. I think he should have outlined a more reasonable goal. Even if he had stopped at "return to the moon", it is still likely more than he will be able to accomplish in his administration, especially when you consider that currently, with our shuttle fleet grounded, we do not even have a vehicle capable of reaching orbit, much less a trip to the moon (the shuttles are ill suited to visit the moon).
 
 A trip to mars is more than a lot of peoplke can envision. A return to the moon, including research for a base there, is a less ambitious goal, but one more likely to be embraced by the population as a whole.
I would call the goals reasonable... the Moon in 10 years and Mars in 26. We could have already gone to Mars if we wanted to... but at a cost of $400 billion.
